review_title: Broadcom is modern IC design company that is maturing
pros:
Broadcom has major differences in culture among business units, so what I write is specific to mine.

Good place to get exposed to analog, digital aspects of chips. Broadcom designs and sells mixed-signal ICs for a variety of applications.

Engineers in Broadcom seem less isolated and compartmentalized as compared to some other modern semiconductor companies.  

Compensation in RSU and Bonus have improved significantly after Broadcom got acquired by Avago in early 2016 (apparently those are positioned at 90th percentile of industry)

Avago management instituted a new tone within Broadcom where all business units are accountable for bringing revenue and finding business. Its much more "sink-or-swim" culture than used to be in old broadcom, but it forced all teams to be more accountable and responsible which is a much healthier approach.
cons:
Semiconductor is slowly turning into an "old" industry so there is much less explosive growth and not as many young creative people who want to join (as opposed to Google, Apple, Facebook, etc). This is an overall trend in semiconductors these days.

Broadcom and other similar companies focus on efficiency of operation (corporate jargon for cost reductions) by reducing perks, eliminating as much as possible spending on non essential things.

Isolation between business units (this is somewhat new after Avago acquisition). 

No perks. Even simple office supplies like pens and paper became hard to find. 

Minimal IT and Facilities support. If you have a problem with the printer or need a new cable it can take days or weeks to resolve. 

Health plan worsened after Avago took over (PPO and HMO with Blue Shield with hefty deductibles of 3k ~ 6k depending on plan, or fully covered Kaiser)

pros: When you work at Broadcom, you get a chance to look at everything from the silicon, to the board, to the kernel, apps, etc. This is a very different mindset in comparison to other companies who use Broadcom products or similar companies chips/board. For example, if you work at networking company, most of the times you will touch some part of the stack or may be some application. Here we do everything.
cons: Work and Life is not fairly balanced. Broadcom is very aggressive in competition which means we almost always promise the sky to the customer and as it happens sometimes deadlines slip and everyone is working late nights or is at customer sight resolving issues from a weeks stay to over a month. If you like to be challenged and not stick to one component (SW/HW) and also like travel then you will love the job (which I do too).

review_title: Great compensation, great tech, long hours, toxic Interpersonal relationships
pros: Great compensation and the ability to work with the latest technology. They really put an emphasis on getting product out the door so the technology to make that happen is the best in the world. Broadcom says they hire only the best of the best and they compensate that way.
cons: Prepare to dislike the people you work with. A lot of toxic relationships. Never before have I worked at a place where I don't trust the people I work with.  That has never happened before. Even my spouse tells me to not trust these people. But the compensation is top notch which means that people stay and gradually adopt the same interpersonal skills of their coworkers to survive. Teamwork suffers.

pros: Free coffee, coke, apple and orange juice.
cons:
They sell you an account management position but then give you an employment contract to sign as an end-user sales engineer and there is a very good reason for this. 
You don't do sales, you are everything and everybody - you are accounting, booking, cash collection, help desk support, invoicing, deep level financial/invoicing problem solver and partner manager however, without any actual infrastructure to support you in these tasks as you are the infrastructure. On top of this mountain of mess there are no tools, historical data or contracts to properly support you in your tasks. There is no presales as CA was cut to zero after the Broadcom takeover so you are also presales but there is no training for you. yet, the expectation to be operational in the second week is there regardless of training. You have to find your own way or go under. It's not sales but administrative work, extenguishing fires and bandaging up deep rifts with the customers and unfullfilled contracts towards them. They package it as 360 account management but experienced people know this has nothing to do with actual account management. It sounds so nice until you start and realize the ship is sinking and you are sinking with it.

review_title: When the CTO uses the phrase "curb engineering inflation", you know you're screwed.
pros:
Great coworkers, and colleagues
Very sharp team, and focused on execution
Immediate management is very capable
cons: Senior management doesn't care about employees. And with Avago buying us, it will be even worse. For a CTO that is suppose to represent the collective engineering mindset, it's a huge discouragement when in all hands meetings, he repeatedly says we need to review our engineering staff and ensure we "curb engineering inflation. Come on, we're all engineers and not stupid. just say what you mean. You think U.S. employees are paid too much, and you want to reduce our compensation package and shift as much work overseas as possible. Calling this "curbing engineering inflation" is just insulting.

pros:
Broadcom Limited really is a new company.  It bears little resemblance to the old Broadcom Corp.  Pro if you hated the old Broadcom?
Broadcom Ltd is better you're in engineering and enjoy "fighting for your job" (words from the CEO) every few months.  Terrible if you're not an engineer (e.g. G&A) because you're doing 4x the work with probably a pay cut.  Sadly, despite all the fighting and bodies being thrown under the bus, it's not like you have the potential financial upside anywhere like working at other companies.
cons: Every 6 MONTHS or so, there's probably a new acquisition.  It doesn't matter that you're the acquiring company, your job may be cut at that time because that's when you're fighting for your job again.  As a result, coworkers may become aggressive, territorial and will not hesitate to throw you under the bus to save their own hide.  Keep this in mind when you're reading reviews pre-2016.  Better yet, you should really search for Avago and read about that company instead.

pros: Broadcom is a a great engineering company built by engineers and not programme managers.
cons: Conditional Access Security is in turmoil since lot of high profile people have resigned now . The leadership/management of  CA Security in UK is dumb technically and are not able able to cope with dynamic requirements of security.  It is time that Broadcom restructure and remove inefficient and incompetent people otherwise competition will get an edge. The current leadership is good at managing a Pub or working at Retail shop and does not deserve working in a great engineering company like Broadcom.  Another issue under the current management is that people at very high grades are doing trivial work here and not contributing what that level demands. Looks like it is heading towards ST micro which shut down its set top group and this will not be surprising.

review_title: In context of a large corporation, generally speaking a solid company to work at.
pros: Being a large company, the pros will vary depending on which group you are in and how you negotiate when coming in and who your boss is. It is a large stable company and weathered quite nicely the housing crash with lots of cash and laying off only a few percent when other companies were axing up to 15%. Engineering staff are excellent (most have PhDs). If you are an engineer, you should be able to colloborate and gain valuable experience. You will typically work on all the latest tools and processes.
cons:
It's a large company with all the normal downsides so you should expect it. The severity of them will depend to a certain degree with the group you are in and the function that you serve. Try to gain an understanding of the issues before hiring by networking if possible.
Hours can sometimes be long, but their infrastructure is expanding, and depending on the group, you may be able to enjoy your weekends much more frequently.

review_title: Dear Software Colleague: Your job description at Broadcom
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Does the following sound like you?


  * Like writing code in a fast pace, yet laid back atmosphere

  * Understand intuitively that software process is over-rated

  * Appreciate that the very best way to do unit testing is during system integration. 

   *Still learning programming but believe that any language invented after C is will never
     work and is unnecessary.

   *Think its awesome that so many of your colleges are hardware engineers - trying their 
    hand at writing product code.
cons:
Broadcom is a hardware company - that now finds itself with a large and growing software problem.
If you know software then you know that building a software system with 200K lines of code is much much
different than building 20 systems that are 10K lines each.  It's like trying to  build a modern sky scraper 
when you've only built garden sheds.

review_title: If I want to work for a Wall Street LBO Shop, I'll Work For a Wall Street Shop, not as an Avago Sweatshop Engineer
pros:
Colleagues are great, and top notch engineers
No-nonsense, talented engineering leaders in the division
cons:
A CEO and CTO that cares more about short term personal profits
A CTO that cares more about the Anaheim Mighty Ducks that he owns
Selling out to the worst possible technology company, Avago

review_title: Good place to enhance technical skills but disastrous people management
pros: Technically rewarding, good pay and benefits
cons:
Very political, no appreciation for good work, quick-to-complain mentality, egoistic and directionless management, no efforts to retain good talent, vacation policy favors only the "buddies-with-boss" employees, lately not enough RSUs, slow promotion cycles, indirect expectation to work late hours/weekends all thru the year.
Caution for new employees - make sure you research about the group and the immediate manager before joining. Certain groups have a track record of eccentric managers harassing people eventually leading to massive exodus.

pros: If nothing else, the people who work at Broadcom are the best. They are intelligent and incredibly hard working. My group always delivers no matter the deadline and no matter the complexity of the project.
cons: The workload is incredible and the compensation seems below average. It is borderline an immigration house mainly because immigrants with phd's are willing to work like this for their green cards.

pros: Good benefits and facilities, on par with regular big companies. Generally nice people and smart engineers. Lots of technical knowledge in the organization.
cons: Time off policies is ridiculous. In theory it is unlimited but in fact it is very dependent on managers' discretion and therefore creating lots of tensions for just getting time-off. Among the six managers/directors in my group, only two of them would actually give people proper time off. Other four director/manager would use any excuse to discourage people taking time off. Engineers who have family/friends overseas BE AWARE! If you ever want to take vacation overseas (> 2 weeks), they would make it really hard. Lots of low-level managers and some directors have ZERO social abilities or management skills. They have no regard of family/personal needs.

review_title: Chaos! No one in management looks more than a few days ahead....
pros: Most of the people you'll work with are smart. Lots of hiring has been going on recently in an attempt to properly staff some projects that have been understaffed for months or years.
cons: Everything about this company is on the decline. Compensation, especially stock compensation, has fallen dramatically, both for new hires and for retention grants with existing employees. The quality of the cafe food and IT support has been declining, the number of social engagements with other employees has been cut to zero (not even a formal holiday party last year), and this is all concurrent with a rising number of projects and customer commitments.  Those who have been there are trying to find their way out and the new ones coming in don't have a good reference point for how good this company used to be.

review_title: Competitive and hardworking engineering team. Uncompetitive and ego driven managers at key positions.
pros:
Plenty of opportunity to learn and explore areas of technical interest
Tools, equipment, access to labs are all excellent
High quality engineering team
Decent recruiting process
Several internal opportunities to explore technical and managerial interests
cons:
Ego driven management contributes to long term weaknesses in competitive abilities in key technical and business areas
Maniacal focus on patent generation results in the production of several useless and redundant activities in the technology creativity process
Unnecessarily hierarchical organizational structure for a company of this size and scope as compared to others of similar size in the semi world. This results in bureaucratic inefficiency when it comes to having certain routine tasks executed.

pros:
Great group of co-workers. Many of whom have been with the company a decade+
On-site cafe which offers "half-off" prices to all employees
On-site gym
Breakrooms with coffee/tea
Competitive benefits including ESPP
Regular team lunches/dinners
Often have flexibility to work from home or take time off when needed
cons:
Penny-wise/pound-foolish policies (not wanting to spend 1k now to save 10k in employee hours wasted)
Bare-bones support staff (very few admins/HR/IT)
IT is mainly offshore and makes the name "help desk" ironic.
There is a general air of "waiting for the axe to fall" ever since the acquisition a few years ago. Many feel the question of if they will be let go is not "if" but "when." Especially if they are on the higher end of the pay scale.

review_title: Mobile platforms is out of shape
pros: Within Broadcom, there are pockets of great people that it is a privilege to work with. Often, their managers don't get it however or they doing the wrong thing, but this doesn't stand in the way of enjoying working with them.
cons: The infinite holiday policy that stops you taking off over 2 weeks without managers approval (and some managers are  idiots and stop this from happening). Majority of the engineers are either not worthy of being employed or worse,  doing mischief instead of real work. Its clear that rivalries between teams is very unhealthy and you end up with countries such as India being 'at war' with other engineering teams for interesting work, reqs or other medals that the company gives out to people with the best strategies.

review_title: -40% YTD stock performance vs. S&P500 or semiconductor sector
pros:
This review is for mobile platform group.  
Basically, work and life can be in balance, except during bring-up or critical issues
Nice campus in Irvine
cons:
If stock is -40% vs S&P500 index, usually the CEO and/or high-level management should take responsibility. The board should notice and do something.
Many critical and expensive mistakes by management, for example bad acquisition of a $400 million LTE company, which turns out to be a dud.  To fix this, another LTE company was acquired.    The mistake is probably reflected in stock price. 
Not seeing any high-level management resigns or leaves over this mistake.

Now, in order to merge, they need to cut cost by letting go good existing people. How about the super top management?

A director also made bad decision over software integration strategy that was costly, but he is still hanging around.

review_title: A decent company with some interesting work, but lots of politics as in most companies
pros: A few interesting technology projects, a fair number of good engineers, not as much arrogance as in some other companies in the San Diego area. Reasonable workload at most times.
cons: A lot of clueless people, especially in management, hence most work is reactive rather than proactive. Lack of vision and planning. In such an environment, the political moves and empty talk, not the quality of your work that typically help you advance your career.

review_title: Great employees and interesting products; senior management is 'so-so'.
pros: Great employees - very experienced and informed. Reasonably flexible with policies and rules. Benefit package is very competive and reasonable generous.
cons: Lots of management churn. Significant cultural shift from the days of 'Nick' to the currnent management. Business units are not very coordinated, in some ways it's almost like they operate as different companies. The HR department seems to be more concerned with pleasing the whims of senior managers and avoiding litigation than attending to the growth and development of the employees.

review_title: Top Notch company to work for
pros: Broadcom provides career opportunities working in cutting edge technologies across a broad spectrum of communication channels.  This includes Ethernet, SATA, PCIe, wireless, 60G wireless and a variety of others.
cons: Broadcom has evolved from a hungry startup to a more stable medium sized company.  This has led to a management evolution from being very aggressive to being much more passive in going after opportunities.  Furthermore, even though Broadcom pays quite well and the work is interesting, management actions leaves many feeling like they are being nickled and dimed on minor things... for instance office supplies are not easily available...  Please note this is a minor gripe in the overall scheme of things.

pros: In some ways my headline is a pro and a con.  Broadcom purchased my company and before the purchase we were all about pleasing the customer.  Sometimes to a fault.  Broadcom seems more about dividing up the clients into the ones that pay us a lot of money and the ones that do not and the service we provide is based on that.  Obviously that is working for them because they are very successful.  But it gives you a sense of not being able to really provide help to the clients that need it if their account is not big enough.  But I listed this as a pro because the profits are passed on to the employees.
cons: Again, to save money, Broadcom uses Google mail, Google chat, etc. and even a smaller "knock-off" product of Salesforce that is cumbersome.  These applications make the day to day job of an employee more difficult.

job_title: Design Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Good payment, good stock price
cons: No good management in some group.  Upper management only cares money and stock.  Company rules are used to punish good employees who follow rules and work professionally. Mangers who cheated and bully are covered by HR.  Normal civil freedom to communicate with people could be limited by the company with ridiculous reason. Employees electronic device could be monitored including your personal cellphone.  Some personal information could be used by some managers to threaten people.

review_title: Good place, getting more bureaucratic with excessive work load....
job_title: Senior Staff Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Chance to work in latest technologies across a broad range of products, smart people who are passionate about what they do.  Flexible work from home policies depending on manager. Professional workplace mostly.
cons: Getting bigger and more bureaucratic. No longer a start up culture. Okay compensation. Does not keep up with market. They stopped stock options years ago. Bonuses are drying up too unless you are a manager and above. Upper management is making out like bandits. They do dole out a few RSUs to the rank and file, but with stock price stagnant or going down, the value is questionable as they don't vest in less than four years. Depending on manager and group, work loads and schedules can be unrealistic and exhausting. No defined vacation time, depends on manager.  Key people have jumped ship.

review_title: The former Broadcom was a great place to work--
pros:
Can do attitude--no politics-total commitment and fun
A strong vision for people and really talented people
A great leader and exceptional global team who achieved a lot-in the right way
Cross cultural and virtual skills massively enhanced as this way or no way here
cons:
Questionable decisions by executive leadership which ultimately cost the business 
Excessive restrictions on travel to the detriment of global working
Some over the top -1950s style bureaucracy which totally contradicted an innovation culture
Commercially and client weak--People leadership a very distant second to Technical

review_title: We are doing well at Mobcom. But we dont exactly control our own destiny. We never have, and this has not changed.
job_title: Senior Staff Hardware Engineer in Irvine, CA
pros:
Broadcom offers a stable workplace. The engineers there are motivated, competent and responsive.  Management does a decent job of communicating goals, achievements and the immediate agenda.
The Mobcom Business Unit where I work has been recently successful at achieving some design wins.
The technology development at Broadcom is very well executed in IC design.
cons: Broadcom has struggled to innovate especially in Mobile Communications Technology. It is a place of execution, not of innovation. The downside is that the focus is always on the short term at Mobile Comm BU.  Middle management  and most staff at Broadcom's Mobile Comm  is mostly focused on internal power struggles and fixed pie calculations within the company rather than a keen focus on the external customer.

pros: Salary is still decent, but almost no other pro's since acquisition.
cons: Job security, favoritism, poor morale

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: I have learned a lot in the cellular division at Broadcom. I -like many others- got the opportunity to go beyond the initial assignments and learn about many system aspects. Internal transfers are easy if not encouraged. Compensation is OK, used to be much better.
cons:
The cellular business got killed by the Beceem acquisition. The VP at Broadcom was buddy with the CEO of Beceem. After 3 years of going nowhere, Broadcom eventually acquired renesas but CEO decided to pull the plug after 9 months. Way to much politics now and those who screwed up never faced the consequence of their acts.
Titles are very much inflated and meaningless. Those who just get a free ride get the same recognition as those who do the work.

review_title: It has become one of the mediocre big company that cannot develop anything new organically.
pros: The pay is fair. It actually pays average people too much and not enough for high performers. The work-life balance is really different from group to group. Promotion opportunities are good, if you like a fancier title every couple of years.
cons: No accountability for upper management. They screwed up so many key decisions but the people should be fired are still up there making ridiculous amount of money. Vacation policy is ridiculous. You supposedly can request unlimited vacation each year. But if you are a responsible person care about the projects you are working on, you would not get any because you do not have time to take vacation.

review_title: Low job security in many teams
pros: Cutting edge research and technology in many teams. Have significant work in India unlike many companies which hoard key research and development work abroad. Opportunities to explore wider range of work, ie switch to a different team internally if there is a partial profile match.
cons: Periodic shutdowns and layoffs. Broadcom works like an octopus. It often cuts off one of its less significant/profit making teams and acquires another one in its stead. So be ready to job hunt if your team is in not doing well. If you do your work well, be prepared to come in saturday and sunday as well. The middle level management doesn't want the lazy ones to work.

review_title: Great company to work for (before Avago acquisition)
pros: This review is for Broadcom before the Avago acquisition.  BRCM has been a great place to work.  People are generally helpful. Good work/life balance. Great medical benefits.  Good pay.
cons: Now that we have been bought by Avago, the morale is very low.  With so much uncertainty, people are losing their motivation.  Everyday there is a new rumor. We are not looking forward to the deal closing and the new management.  I do not recommend BRCM to anyone now because of the M&A.  Up until now, BRCM has been a good company to work for.

pros: Decent bonuses (if your division meets its goals) & RSUs, fine benefits (but worse than CA's), 401k match up to a certain point, Rally still values work-life balance.
cons: They are a hardware company and have no interest in meeting the needs of a modern software company. They don't have much empathy for humans & the values of the broader company are very money-centric. We've lost a lot of people and are losing more because we're being forced to move to Broomfield from Denver and Boulder. That puts pressure on the business unit and every individual and forces continual, often difficult change. Rally still has some great people, but it is being forced to be a much more corporate culture.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: A few employees, particularly Electrical Engineering managers and directors, are happy because they have a good pay package and vacation allocation.
cons:
All other employees such as mid level electrical engineers, software managers, analysts, IT department staff, and operations staff are paid under their market rate. 

There is discrimination between teams. If your team works on product or module that is important to the company then the people in this team get better treatment from the management - easier purchase approvals, more vacation days, and higher pay. One senior sales person actually got excused for installing adult content software on his computer ! Teams that work daily to support these teams such as operations and other engineering staff get the opposite treatment.

Not a safe place to work for. San Jose, CA location had laptop stolen from inside of the premises and there was no recording on camera of the act. Can't leave your valuables at your desk at this place.

pros: There are still a few good people but they are exiting as fast as they can.  There really isn’t anything positive to say anymore.
cons: Brutal environment.  If they owed their mom ten cents they would spend 5 dollars on figuring out a way to beat her out of it.  And if they couldn’t figure out a way to beat her out of it, they would just not pay her.  It is ALL about Hoc Tan.  This is his playground and the feeling is that you should be happy just to be there because he is so much smarter than you.  Because of the environment you will run into people who will just do the bare minimum and you can’t blame them.

job_title: R & D Engineer in Bangalore Rural
pros:
1. Good pay, good bonus and one (especially senior grade employees) can make a lot of money from RSUs if you survive on that year.
2. Notice period is just one month.
3. Flexible timings and WFH option is available if manager approves it.
cons:
1. No job security since lot of firings are happening at each and every quarter end.
2. No hiring due to cost cutting and so more workload among team members.
3. No facilities like gym, dormitory in the new Electronic city location
4. No team outings and no work culture.
5. No cubical workspace and it is like row type. It's too congested and you would hit the person sitting behind you if you move little bit. No privacy.
6.  RSUs will be vested only at March end and you won't get it if you are fired before fourth quarter.
7. No proper roadmap due to lot of acquisitions.
8. No transparency among the management.
9. No work life balance if you are not staying in electronic city location

Classic Broadcom - Heaven
Avago acquired Broadcom - Hell

review_title: Decent work-life balance, few learning opportunities
pros:
Compensation is fair
Well respected company
Work hours can (potentially) be flexible, depending on team and work schedule.  Usually only a few hours of budge room, but this allows employees to enjoy group sports on a weekly basis
cons:
Team silos don't encourage collaboration/knowledge sharing
Not a lot of opportunity for self-development
Passive aggressive tendencies between some colleagues
Once leadership has decided on a project, the course is set.  Work on that project will continue whether or not it seems to be a good fit to the teams on the ground.  Transparency on decision-making at this level could be improved, but that's one of the realities of a 11k+ organization.

job_title: Principal Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Excellent engineering-focused environment. Broadcom started with a lot of core technical knowledge and has continued to acquire more every year. Large percentage of Engineers and PhD's in the workforce. Startup-like mentality means plans move ahead quickly for corresponding market success.
cons: Risk of burnout; projects with less upside or longer payback have a hard time getting funded. Your experience may vary depending on which part of Broadcom emplys you - as an ongoing roll-up of many startups there is always cultural integration in process at various stages in various places. Another problem with the acquisition strategy is that founders or key members may leave the newly-acquired division quickly. Especially true now the share price is lower.

pros: Excellent pay and great stock performance.  Benefits are good, 401K is excellent.  If you solely care about making money then this will be a good fit.
cons: Run super lean, lots of work, lonely environment, not open to gaining efficiency.  Buys companies all the time, COA environment because people are scared to lose their jobs, always adding more work while driving headcount down.  Runs flat so hard to grow.  No work life balance, you are always on call.

review_title: poor culture with too many upper management
pros:
good compensation which are in line or above market 
good benefits with great health coverage and low salary deductions 
fly biz class on trips
corporate credit card so you never have to pay your own expenses
cons:
will aggressively recruit you and tell you what you want to hear to get you in
too many "senior execs" who do nothing but push you and go to meetings 
a culture of "i'll talk to you because i need something" and border line college hazing before you get any respect
their ESPP purchase and 401k wealth management firm is horrible and confusing 
they let you fly business, but as soon as a cheaper fare is found, you have to take it, even a few nights before your trip and it greatly affects the time you leave and the layover time (from no layover to a 4 hour layover!)
no career path movement and growth - do what we tell you

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Irvine, CA
pros:
Competitive salary, good work/life balance, low meeting overhead.  Broadcom is a place where they let you get work done.  Meetings are often scheduled in the evenings to allow multiple continents to attend, and the later ones can be attended from home over the phone.

Many groups allow flexible hours once you prove yourself able to get work done.
cons:
Marketing driven engineering, corporate attitude, slow growth.  It can be hard for an engineering sourced feature to get a green light, and it's easier to give up rather than convince all the right people.

It's getting more "big corporate" attitude every year and every penny counts to management now.  Freebies and celebrations are much harder to come by than they once were, and bonuses are awarded less often.

pros: Great smart people at Broadcom. There is a sense of accomplishment and a roadmap for the future.
cons: Avago bought Broadcom and disected the company. There is no more future for the employees. Everything revolves around the stock going up. They will do anything to make the stock go up. This is good as a shareholder. But as an employee, the company will abuse you.

pros: - it is a stable job
cons:
-When I ask to recommend a friend of mine into the group manager tells me that we are on a hiring "Freeze" and weeks later we hire more people and they are all related to the managers.
- Managers tell me that vacation is not a benefit but a privilege.
- Vacation takes months to be approved, vacation emails gets ignored even when they have company phones to check emails regularly. 
- Procedures are made on the spot. When I try to take a 2 week vacation manager tells me I need to put in the request 6m-1y in advance, when I did just that manager tells me my request is too long from now and wont approve.
- Favors on top of favors on family related employees.
- its not about skills but more about who you know and who you are related to.

job_title: Rnd Software Engineer III in Bangalore
pros:
1. Very decent compensation (best in the industry I suppose),  especially the stock (RSU) benefits
2.  Technically sound people around and to work with.
3. Satisfactory career growth opportunities
cons:

2. Company is run with all finance aspects in mind and the employee friendly policies are going away, every passing year. No Team Outing or any such engagements any more (this too depends on the respective BUs though).
3. Work life balance is not adequate in a few BUs.

pros: Broadcom is a great company to work for. The compensation great and definitely higher than most other companies located in the OC. There are 2 gyms and 2 cafes at the headquarters. People here are very smart, and it's rare to be working with an incompetent idiot here. Work life balance is different with every team, but all my friends and myself included rarely have to work long hours. The pay is very fair for the number of hours put in.
cons: People at Broadcom seem to be more closed off to each other. Most buildings at the Irvine campus have hallways of offices, no bullpens or open space..so people tend to just stay in their offices and not socialize as much. There also aren't very many networking opportunities or ways to meet others at work.

review_title: Horrible experience - not a good place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Duluth, GA
pros:
- Good salary, free drinks like coffee and soda in the office,

- If money and salary matters more than work-life balance good place to stay if you can handle horrible treatment by managers and upper management

pros: was a good technology learning environment.

review_title: Was OK to work as an intern.

review_title: Above average yet typical big hardware company

review_title: "It was the best of times, it was the worst of times" -- an extreme experience for 2-3 years, or until you burn out
pros:
Everyone knows Broadcom is one of the L33T (that's pronounced 'ELITE') semiconductor companies in the area.  YOU work with the best ... period.  And so do they ... (assuming YOU made it through a straight on-site interview (not through some backdoor internal referral.)  Once you've worked there in a technical role for a year or more (and assuming you don't get fired), then seek work elsewhere, Irvine employers KNOW just how L33T you are (again, assuming you have positive professional references to back it up.)

I found the communication among the (engineering) technical staff was quite open.  People were always madly busy, but would still put in a good effort to answer your questions (or point you in the proper direction.)  I worked at other places where you need to "ask permission from the other manager", just to step into another guy's office (... I mean, like elementary school!) so this openess and flat-organization was great for getting occasional technical advice.

Just about all IT/engineering assets available through VPN.  (**COUGH** MARVELL **COUGH**) Every employee was issued a laptop to take to meetings/home, at least I got one and I wasn't even special.
cons:
Everyone said it -- long, long, LONG, dungeonmaster work hours.  Marvell would be proud beyond reason!

 On really critical cornerstone projects, some managers dictate no vacation/time-off allowed during project tape-out (doesn't sound so bad until mangement tells you 'tape-out' period can start 4-5+ months ahead of final GDSII release, and too many projects designated 'critical')  

Just about all IT/engineering assets available through VPN -- now you have NO EXCUSE for not working past 10pm.
When I was on a 'critical SoC project', about 1/3 of my emails arrived between 8pm and 2am (same timezone!)  TO keep up, you pretty much have to match the other vampires, otherwise ye dungeonmaster may notice your emails are conspicuously absent during those normal workhours (8pm-2am)

Although the technical excellence showed everywhere, unrealistic workload (and poor planning) interfered with execution.  In some ways, Broadcom is a victim of its own success.  In the early years, the frantic work-schedule (typical of  silicon-valley startups) was the rule, and indeed, propelled Broadcom to success.  But that should have just been a phase, with a transition to a more sustainable development-flow and strategy.  Having every group run their employees into the ground (until they burnout) is not a sustainable management style.

review_title: Review for CCX group in original Broadcom
pros:
This review is for CCX (compute and connectivity) group in original Broadcom (prior to Avago acquired it in 2016 and took its name). Pros are-
* work from home facility (might become restricted due to Avago in future)
* work life balance to some extent 
* Because of these and the brand value, i have given it 3star rating.
cons:
- When layoff is done, employee' access is disabled the very next day. The management doesn't even bother to consider that all the while the employees were working on projects and how they will prepare for interview without access to work databses. This disabling of access within 1-2 day is the norm here. I have seen it in my group as well as other 3-4 groups in which layoff happened in 2016 after Avago acquired it.
* HR policies are turning worse after Avago acquisition. For example: if an employee decides to leave the company without serving notice period of 1 month, employee will have to pay 1 month salary. But if after the employee gives resignation, the company can end the employment without giving any compensation for the notice period. 
* Number of leaves have reduced from 18 to 15. Holidays are 10 in an year. This is less as compared to industry standard.
* A major portion of the pay is given in terms of RSUs which is not good because when you leave, the unvested RSUs go away and you are not able to show a good baseline to your next employer so I'd say negotiate in the beginning itself to have cash instead of RSU.
- Politics within sub-teams in bangalore. If one sub-team manager gets a chance, he will promote only his sub-team reportees and the other sub-team members will not be promoted even though being more competent.
- Lot of politics between india vs US teams. 
- Upper management favors US team thats why layoff in Dec 2016 was fully done in bangalore team and none in US team. In shared projects, most credit goes to US team and most blame comes to india team. 
- Most of the work is moving to US and hence india employees feel that there will be more layoffs in the coming years. This group is highly unstable at this time.

pros:

Some teams are led by excellent managers and full of smart and helpful people, others consist of mediocre employees led by poor managers. If you interview, definitely complete any due diligence that you can - don't take an offer blindly unless you are exceptionally preceptive of people at first impressions. I would say that some groups are apolitical, where people are often helpful; others are cutthroat and arguably for no good reason. There are lots of people that have been here a long time and have no incentive or desire to leave. This means that there is a lot of knowledge sharing, but also fewer opportunities to shift around. The best thing about working here, at least for me, is that your immediate team tries to bring you up to their skill level and backstabbing isn't something you have to worry about.

Basically, every team has its own character; some great, but some terrible; most are quite technically capable - the shortcomings are elsewhere.
cons:
The odds of moving up from a development role into any sort of management is slim. The management structure tries to remain flat - while good for effectiveness and efficiency, it is poor for future opportunities (not that this matters to me or most engineers, but it's something to be aware of). Compensation is mediocre; we had all our options taken away but little else to make up for that shortfall, although my understanding is that this was a widespread occurence.

Only two weeks of vacation is a much lower number than you'd expect from a tech company. In general, all of the "auxiliary" benefits that you'd expect from tech companies of this size aren't there.  There's no amenities to speak of (at my location). What kind of tech company doesn't have any common space whatsoever on a site with 500+ employees? This means no cafeteria, no fitness faciltiies; the quality of the that is brought from the San Jose facities goes from terrible to disgusting; whether or not food even shows up is always inconsistent, and there's no response to feedback regarding how terrible it is. What this translates to is that in a typical day, you show up, you bring your lunch, you do your work, you go home. What kind of company, much less a tech one, doesn't offer commuter checks in 2008? You're in walking distance from Sunnyvale caltrain yet this is the only company I am aware of that doesn't do a commuter check system.

Come here to learn a technical field well and learn from smart people. Don't expect more.

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
* It's a big company with a lot of diverse products, so if you're an engineer then chances are good you will find some interesting job opportunities.  Moving around within the company to work on different technologies is not discouraged and I've seen a number of engineers do it.

* Good market penetration, meaning that most likely whatever you are working on either is or will be shipping in good quantities to major customers.  This can be a nice change of pace after working at startup companies who may not have been able to get much traction.  It's nice to be able to list a bunch of gadgets that everyone has heard of, which contain software/chips that you have worked on.

* Base compensation is at best average, but stock plans (restricted stock, stock options, ESPP) augment the salary pretty nicely, especially after a few years of additional stock grants.  Cash bonuses are paid to good performers - not huge ones, but still welcome.

* Raises for good performers are pretty competitive, promotions seem to be fairly distributed to those who have earned them.

* Company has a bit of a reputation as a sweatshop, but this depends very strongly upon which group you are in.  No one in my group works weekends or ridiculous hours, nor are we expected to.  Managers (in my group, at least) do a very good job at defining schedules that are ambitious but achievable without "death marches".

* Schedules and work arrangements are very flexible.  Lots of people work from home much of the time, no mandate to be at work during specific hours other than to participate in meetings, which are mercifully few.

* Better than average engineers, both in terms of core knowledge and in terms of work ethic and engineering judgment.  Not much deadwood, unlike some places I've worked.
cons:
* Stingy vacation time: 2 weeks to start with, +1 day per year of service, up to 4 weeks maximum.  An extra week wouldn't kill them, and it would greatly improve quality of life for employees.

* Jobs are very concentrated in California. It would be cool to see a presence in some of the other tech hubs around the country.

* Cafeteria has gone way downhill: more expensive, crappier food.
